title: migration big issue eu brexit james forsyth
story: They are acutely aware that for the EU 27 Brexit isn’t the biggest issue on the agenda, migration is.One Government source tells me: “It’ll be a non-event. They’ve far too much to discuss among themselves.”Migration is plunging European politics into crisis again. German Chancellor Angela Merkel’s coalition is threatening to break apart over the issue.While in Italy, the new government is threatening to close its southern border — blocking migrant rescue ships from landing — and open its northern border, encouraging illegal migrants and asylum seekers to head north to Germany and Sweden.So worried is European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker that he is hosting a mini-summit tomorrow to try to find a solution to the migrant crisis which can help save Merkel’s political career.It is tempting to look at the EU in crisis and say that is why the UK is leaving. But this crisis is making it more difficult for Britain to get a reasonable Brexit deal.The European Commission is running the Brexit negotiations.Its priority is in defending the theology of the European Union, rather than finding practical solutions. As one leading figure in the Government laments to me, Brussels’ chief negotiator Michel Barnier “won’t budge off CETA (Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement) with Northern Ireland stuck in the customs union”.This kind of Canada-style free trade deal is regarded by the Government as inadequate.Mrs May and co have long hoped that the member states, nearly all of whose economies would be hurt by such a limited agreement, would intervene at some point and tell the Commission to engage more constructively with the UK. But this is happening all too rarely.One of the reasons is, in the words of one member of the Brexit inner Cabinet: “Only four national capitals are fully across Brexit.”Many of the countries that are most sympathetic to the UK don’t have the capacity to follow all of the issues concerned.Over the past few years, the key to any deal in Europe has been Merkel. She is not now going to ride to Britain’s rescue— as David Cameron found to his cost in the renegotiation.But the German Chancellor could push the Commission towards a slightly more pragmatic approach.However, she is now trying to keep her own governing coalition together, as well as come up with a deal with the French for eurozone reform, leaving next to no time for Brexit.I am told that when Brexit is discussed in meetings she is “visibly distracted”, turning to aides for advice far more frequently than she does on other issues.This situation is one of the many reasons why the Government should have prepared vigorously for no deal: A credible threat to walk away from the table if the Commission didn’t behave in a reasonable fashion would have got the member states’ attention.But Mrs May now must hope the EU can patch together some deal on migration and that the member states begin thinking seriously about what kind of post-Brexit relationship they want with this country.WHEN the Cabinet gathers at Chequers next month to thrash out the UK’s offer to the EU, one of the most contentious issues will be customs.The Brexit inner Cabinet is split between those who favour a so-called “new customs partnership” (NCP) with the EU – which would see the UK continue to apply EU tariffs after Brexit, with companies receiving a rebate if their goods stayed in Britain rather than heading to the continent – and those who advocate Max Fac, which would use technology to minimise border checks.Two Cabinet working groups are trying to find a way to make these ideas work. Neither group has had a decisive breakthrough yet. But I am told the Max Fac one is “not a million miles away” from a solution.The challenge for the PM is to make these plans acceptable to her own side, including David Davis and Liam Fox. One Brexit inner Cabinet member tells me: “She’s got to have David and Liam. If she doesn’t have them, then she has no solution.”Both Davis and Fox support the Max Fac option. But there are influential figures in No10 who remain convinced that NCP is the option to go for. They argue only NCP can help deal with the Irish border issue and get the Government through next month’s crucial Commons votes on the customs union. They warn: “No NCP, no Brexit.”The fear among Brexiteers is Mrs May will use this Chequers meeting to try to push through a modified version of NCP. They fear the reason the whole Cabinet will be present on the second day is to give Mrs May the numbers to do this if the Brexit inner Cabinet remains split on the issue.Doing this, though, would be extremely risky. It would leave Mrs May with a policy that neither her Brexit Secretary nor her International Trade Secretary support.THE Chancellor and the Defence Secretary aren’t just split over how much money the military should get, but what it should be spent on, too.One Cabinet ally of Philip Hammond’s complains that Gavin Williamson wants to “spend the money on uniformed officers when he should be spending it on robotics and the like”.Their view is that this would be a better response to the 21st-century security challenges Britain faces.But in truth, Britain needs both conventional and new, hi-tech forces if it is to respond to the variety of threats now out of there. That is why we MUST spend more on defence.Those close to Williamson point out that if the Government doesn’t increase the defence budget, our status as the leading military spender in Europe – upon which so much of our influence in the world depends – will be under threat as the French and the Germans increase their military budgets.NEXT week, Theresa May will give a speech setting out the Government’s post-Brexit industrial strategy.Key to this must be artificial intelligence, an area where we are one of the leading nations in the world.I understand that the importance of maintaining the UK’s edge in AI is what led to Mrs May accepting Home Secretary Sajid Javid and Digital Secretary Matt Hancock’s argument that visa rules for tech entrepreneurs must be relaxed.The countries that succeed at AI will end up defining this century.So any deal with the EU must preserve the UK’s ability to regulate these industries of the future in a way decided by us, not Brussels.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the sun says theresa may brexit bold move
story: So much damage has been done to Britain since June 23, 2016 — not by the vote, but by the refusal of hardcore Remainers to accept it.They are not of course to blame for all the chaos. It is staggering that the ­Government is still undecided on ­fundamental principles.But the Tories’ woes were hugely exacerbated by their election calamity, caused in part by Remainers hoping Labour would betray Brexit.That emboldened diehards in the Lords and Commons — operating alongside the lavishly-funded, slickly orchestrated campaign colluding with Brussels to annul the biggest vote in our history.Meanwhile the national conversation has degenerated into a tsunami of hate, chiefly from sanctimonious Remainers branding Leavers uneducated racists.How much better off we would all now be if on June 24, 2016 they had grudgingly accepted defeat and pledged instead to make the best of Brexit.In fairness, some Remainers did. TV’s Richard Madeley spoke for them recently when he said we now had a duty to see it through in full by leaving the single market and customs union.He was right. To pretend that Brexit can be “softened” to honour the substantial Remain vote — a nightmarish fudge which Boris Johnson warns of today — is simply dishonest. There is leaving and there is remaining. That’s it.Brussels has revelled in Britain tearing itself apart. Now it is sidetracked by its own problems. A deal looks miles off.Theresa May has only one path forward. At next month’s pivotal vote, she must defeat the backbench rebellion hoping to shackle us to a customs union restricting our trading future. That is not Brexit, as voters would quickly realise. It would reignite the Leave ­campaign with unprecedented ferocity.And the PM and her Cabinet must not be derailed by Remain-fanatic businesses muttering about pulling out. Previous such threats have proved bogus, like all those dire economic forecasts.Leaving may not be smooth in the short-term. That must not deter us.When the EU finally realises Brexit in full is inevitable maybe they will stop playing games and agree a deal.But if the Remain resistance succeeds in crippling Brexit, it will bring on chaos.Our current divisions will seem like happy hour. title: hms queen elizabeth ii aircraft carrier returns portsmouth
story: HMS Queen Elizabeth is the largest aircraft carrier ever commissioned by the Navy and weighs in at a whopping 65,000 tons.The jewel of the Royal Navy sailed into the Hampshire port at around 9am this morning, after another trial at sea.Incredible images show the massive ship dwarfing tugboats that were helping it manoeuvre into port.She has returned from her latest series of work-ups and trials, so crew can get used to the ship and stretch their sea legs.The £3.1billion super ship was first launched in December and was named after a super-dreadnought from the First World War.Britains armed forces are massively bolstered by the massive threat posed to any enemies by the colossal aircraft carrier - which can carry up to 60 planes.It is staffed by around 650 crew and can travel more than half way around the world before needing to be refuelled.Her sister ship is named HMS Prince of Wales, and is the eighth to bear that name.In August 2017, the colossal vessel was pictured during her sea trials off the coast of Scotland, alongside USS Donald Cook, USS Philippine Sea and the colossal American carrier USS George HW Bush.Experts reckon the ship is expected to remain in Portsmouth for resupply for a couple of weeks, until being deployed to the US later this summer.HMS Queen Elizabeth set sail from the Rosyth dockyard in Fife on June 26.The 65,000-tonne carrier passed under the iconic Forth Road Bridge, then spending several weeks in the North Sea for sea trials.She arrived in Portsmouth Harbour on August 16, 2017, sharing the message home on social media as it came into the naval base.Captain Jerry Kyd said he felt a huge amount of pride ahead of the vessel berthing in her home port.On November 22, 2017, HMS Queen Elizabeth returned from the second period of sea trials.The giant ship made port in Portsmouth on June 23, 2018 after the latest Helicopter Sea Trials.The Royal Navy’s new aircraft carrier had a leak so serious it may need to go back into dry dock at Rosyth — for repairs that will cost millions.A faulty seal around one of the vast warship’s propeller shafts meant 200 litres of sea water poured in every hour.Sources said at the time there was a “significant” defect with the stern seal, an inflatable rubber ring that fits around one of the propeller shafts.The problem was spotted during sea trials.It reportedly had the fault when it was delivered by ship building partnership the ­Aircraft Carrier Alliance, which could mean they will have to pay for the repairs, not the Ministry of Defence.The aircraft carrier spent six weeks in the North Sea for sea trials.During the trip, the aircraft undertook handling and speed tests off the east coast of Scotland.The Queen officially welcomed the UK’s new £3.1billion aircraft carrier into the Royal Navy fleet and declared it the “best of British”.Her Maj arrived on board HMS Queen Elizabeth in an elegant purple outfit, at Portsmouth Naval base on December 7.She underwent sea trials with Chinook and Merlin helicopters in March 2018.The two helicopter type trials were carried out in tandem, ensuring the time available on deck was used to maximum effect and avoiding a second voyage out to sea later in the year.It is due to head to America’s east coast for F-35 flight trials which will begin in October 2018.The HMS Queen Elizabeth will be declared as having a full operational capability in 2020.During her estimated 50-year working life, HMS Queen Elizabeth could be pressed into action for various work such as high-intensity war fighting or providing humanitarian aid and disaster relief anywhere in the world.Each aircraft carrier will provide the armed forces with a four-acre military operating base, which can be deployed worldwide.When the ship has its full complement of 36 F-35B fighters and four helicopters on board the crew will increase to about 1,600.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cedella roman french jogger detained us canada border
story: Cedella Roman, 19, unknowingly ran into the United States last month after running south down a beach in White Rock, British Columbia.As the tide came in, she jogged up a path to take a photo - at which point two border patrol officers told her she had been seen jogging into Washington state.She told The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation: I told him I had not done it on purpose, and that I didnt understand what was happening.I said to myself, well I may have crossed the border - but theyll probably only give me a fine or theyll tell me to go back to Canada or theyll give me a warning.But when officers realised she didnt have a passport, they locked her in a van before driving her 120 miles to the infamous Tacoma Northwest detention facility.She added: They asked me to remove all my personal belongings with my jewellery, they searched me everywhere.Then I understood it was getting very serious, and I started to cry a bit.Mum Christine soon rushed to the facility with her daughters passport - but Cedella was locked up for another fortnight while Canadian authorities verified their authenticity.A spokesperson for the US customs and border protection told CBC that anyone who enters the US outside an official port of entry and without inspection has crossed the border illegally and will be detained.

title: iain duncan smith theresa may brexit talks
story: Senior allies want the PM to seize ­control of negotiations now the flagship departure bill is set to become law.And if EU officials rebuff her demands, she should hand over her business card and say: “Call me if you change your minds. I’m out of here.”Former Conservative leader Iain Duncan Smith has told Mrs May to turn the tables on “bullying” Eurocrats when she returns to Brussels this week.He believes she is in her strongest ­position yet to get them to discuss their relationship with Britain when we leave on March 29 next year.In the 15 months since Article 50 was triggered, they have refused to discuss trade while our own MPs argued among themselves.But Mrs May’s hand was strengthened last week after she saw off the rebels to get the EU Withdrawal Bill through ­Parliament.Tory MP Mr Duncan Smith warned she must show her mettle as she faces the biggest test of any PM in peacetime at next week’s Brussels showdown.He told The Sun on Sunday: “Theresa May now has the upper hand in these talks.They have been watching us fight among ourselves over Brexit for months and didn’t have to do anything because her position was so weak.“They knew there was an outside chance it wouldn’t happen, so they’ve dug in on all the practical stuff such as trade and bogged us down with other details.“But now it has been voted through. We are leaving. They cannot stop it.“I’ve advised Theresa to tell them bluntly to agree to talk about trade or she is leaving.“If they refuse to engage, she must have the resolve to get up and leave the table — making clear she will take our ­£40billion contribution with her.“Theresa must put her cards on the table and tell them she wants to talk about trade now.“If they tell her they don’t want to, she should put her business card on the table and say ‘Tell you what.There’s my ­number. Give me a buzz if you change your minds.Meanwhile, we’ve got nothing more to say to you’.“Then she should turn to her aides and say, ‘We can catch the ten past six if we hurry now.Can you get some cars because we’re on our way.We’ve got work to do. Nice to see you all. OK, guys. Take care. Goodbye!’“That will bring them to their senses rather quickly.“The 27 other EU countries are desperate for a deal so they can sell us their cars, cheeses and potato products.“They’ve tried to push us around for the past couple of years but Theresa has the upper hand now and she must show them who’s boss.”Slamming the way EU officials have treated Britain as “disgusting”, Mr Duncan Smith said: “Undiplomatic doesn’t begin to cover it.“They’ve done their level best to ­humiliate and be rude to us. They are meant to be our friends and allies.”Singling out chief negotiator Michel Barnier, European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker and ­European Parliament co-ordinator Guy Verhofstadt, he added: “Come this week, we can tell them their days of behaving like ­playground bullies are over.”He said Wednesday’s flagship vote was THE most significant bill passed in the Commons since the treaty to join the fledgling ­European Economic Community in 1973.Crucially, it removes any chance of Brexit being derailed and the clock really has begun ticking towards our departure in 278 days.Brexiteers now warn that the PM must finalise a deal by November, to leave time to clear it all by February.Mr Duncan Smith said: “She is in a stronger position than she’s been in for some months.Getting the most critical bit of legislation through last week means she goes to the European Council knowing our departure is now settled.“That means she is back in charge of the negotiation and there is no way they can stop Brexit.“Now it’s down to raw negotiation, and the question facing the EU is how much they want to have a good relationship.“We do, and the Prime Minister has been open about that. But she has to be ready to walk away.“I’ve done negotiations in business and that’s what you do. You say, ‘There’s nothing on the table that I can agree to here. Sorry, I’m off’.“Never buy a car until you’ve attempted to walk out of the showroom at least twice.There is no better way to get the price down than to say, ‘I’m off, it’s too expensive, I’ll go somewhere else.’It’s not so much calling their bluff. It’s calling them out.“It’s kind of like poker — and Theresa has to force them to show their hand.”Last week’s decision to pump an extra £20billion into the NHS — partly funded by savings from EU contributions — will also send a clear message to Brussels that Britain is leaving.Mr Duncan Smith said: “It’s a down-payment that says we have to leave.“It shows she knows we’re leaving and we won’t be paying them any more money after a set time.”But has Mrs May got what it takes to face down the Brussels bully boys?Mr Duncan Smith said: “I think she has the steel to surprise them.“We’ve seen before what she’s like when she really digs her heels in. And there’s never been a better moment for her to do it than now.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The Trade Supremo insisted it wouldn’t bother him if the transition period was extended by “a few extra months”.It put him at odds with the Foreign Secretary who is eager to leave and warned the PM not to allow the process drag on. title: saudi arabia women driving ban ends
story: The change was ordered by King Salman in September last year - with the first licences issued earlier this month - but it wasnt formally lifted until today.Saudi Arabia was the only country in the world where women werent allowed to drive and the strict rules were enforced despite neither Islamic or Saudi law explicitly prohibiting female drivers.It was a historic moment for women who have had to rely on their husbands, fathers, brothers and drivers to run basic errands, get to work, visit friends or even drop kids off at school.Hessah al-Ajaji, who drove her familys Lexus down the capitals busy Tahlia Street, said: Im speechless. Im so excited its actually happening.She had a US drivers license before obtaining a Saudi one and appeared comfortable at the wheel as she pulled up and parked.As for the male drivers on the road, she said: They were really supportive and cheering and smiling.In a few hours, she says shell drive herself to work for the first time in Saudi Arabia.Samira al-Ghamdi, 47, one of the first Saudi women to be issued with a driving licence, said: We are ready, and it will totally change our life.Saudi women with foreign licences only began converting them earlier this month, so the number of new drivers is expected to remain low at first.It will be some time before others learning to drive at new state-run schools are road ready, while some women still face resistance from conservative relatives.Many accustomed to using a private driver say they are reluctant to take on the Muslim kingdoms busy highways.Fayza al-Shammary, a 22-year-old saleswoman, said: I definitely wont like to drive.I like to be a princess with someone opening the car door for me and driving me anywhere.The change is part of sweeping reforms by the kings son Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, who aims to transform the economy of the worlds top oil exporter.The lifting of the ban, which for years drew international condemnation, has been welcomed by Western allies as proof of a new progressive trend in Saudi Arabia.For nearly three decades, outspoken Saudi women and the men who supported them had called for women to have the right to drive.They faced arrest for defying the ban as women in other Muslim countries drove freely.In 1990, during the first driving campaign by activists, women who got behind the wheels of their cars in the capital, Riyadh, lost their jobs, faced severe stigmatisation and were barred from travel abroad for a year.Ultraconservatives in Saudi Arabia had long warned that allowing women to drive would lead to sin and expose women to harassment.Ahead of allowing women to drive, the kingdom passed a law against sexual harassment with up to five years prison for the most severe cases.Criticism against women driving has largely been muted since since King Salman announced last year that they would be allowed to drive.Simultaneously, however, at least 10 of the most outspoken supporters of womens rights were arrested just weeks before the ban was lifted.

title: royal wedding thomas markle morning suit pr meghan
story: Thomas Markle, 73, had been set to walk his daughter down the aisle at Windsor Castle for her big day but was unable to attend after suffering a heart attack.Instead the suit was left on the peg at upmarket Chelsea outfitters Oliver Brown.That is until Johnno Spence visited the shop and picked up the semi-bespoke morning suit at a knock-down price of £2,000.Meghan, now the Duchess of Sussex, is said to have personally commissioned the company’s owner Kristian Robson to make several outfits for her father, not just the suit for the wedding.The list included three shirts with size 18 collars and double cuffs, in blue, yellow and white a navy blue weekend suit a single-breasted waistcoat and a set of tails.A source told The Daily : When Johnno walked in, the tailor said: We’ve got the perfect morning suit for you as well as a summer suit and three shirts for you if you want them.Spence is said to have paid £2,000 for the items, around half the normal price and proudly wore the morning suit to Ascot.Oliver Brown, established 35 years ago, is the official tailor of Royal Ascot, where a top hat and tails are compulsory for Royal Enclosure guests.Spences PR firm, JSC Communications counts jockey Ryan Moore, National Hunt rider Nico de Boinville and Champion Apprentice jockey Josephine Gordon as clients.

title: fat content menus child obesity
story: New laws are being drawn up by the government to ensure parents can make an informed choice about what they feed their kids.Experts believe they will eat less if they know the fat content of fast food such as kebabs, pizza and curry before they order.The calorie count scheme is part of a package of measures aimed at halving the number of obese children within 12 years.Supermarkets will be banned from displaying sweets and chocolate at checkouts to stop kids using “pester power” on their parents.There will also be a crackdown on buy-one-get-one-free deals on unhealthy food.Tough new restrictions will be place on TV and online advertising of sugary or fatty products aimed at children.Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt will consult food and retail chains about his action plan.He said: “The cost of obesity – both on individual lives and our NHS – is too great to ignore.“So we are taking steps to ensure that by 2030, children from all backgrounds have the help they need for a healthier, more active start in life.”The crackdown on foods high in sugar, fat and salt will be coupled with initiatives to keep children active.All primary schools will expected to encourage pupils to run or jog a mile a day, or cycle to lessons.The action will stop short of banning cartoon characters from popular brands – such as Tony the Tiger on Frosties or Percy Pig sweets.But the current advertising watershed will be extended to limit the number of unhealthy food commercials show during family viewing time before 9pm.There is evidence that popular TV programmes are saturated with ads for sweet and fattening products.Companies will also be given new incentives to reduce the sugar and calorie content in the products they sell.Mr Hunt will consult on introducing clear and consistent calorie labelling on all menus – and removing tempting treats from checkouts.He added: “It is near impossible to shield children from exposure to unhealthy foods.“Parents are asking for help. We know that over three-quarters of them find offers for sugary sweets and snacks at checkouts annoying.“It’s our job to give power to parents to make healthier choices and to make their life easier in doing so.”Last night the obesity plan received broad support.Alison Tedstone, chief nutritionist at Public Health England, said: “Having a takeaway or eating out is no longer a treat, it’s a regular part of everyday life, yet too often menus are information free zones.“Clear and consistent information on menus at the point of choice is the bold commitment needed to help families make healthier choices and avoid obesity-related health problems.”Some supermarkets already restrict sales to under-16s after calls from teachers and experts.Ministers must decide on a 16 or 18 age limit. Research shows the drinks can trigger unruly and dangerous behaviour.Caroline Cerny, of the Obesity Health Alliance, added: “The plan crucially addresses the issue of children being continually exposed to junk food adverts when they watch their favourite TV shows and when they go online.”Chris Askew, of Diabetes UK, said: “With one in three children either overweight or obese before they leave primary school, it’s clear that bold, decisive action needs to be taken. Being overweight as a child can significantly increase your risk of developing serious conditions like Type 2 diabetes in the future.”But Advertising Association chief Stephen Woodford said: “UK advertising rules are already among the strictest in the world.“International experience and independent research has shown advertising bans have little impact on the wider societal issues that drive obesity, which is caused by the interaction of many complex factors and requires a multi-faceted solution.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: british school kids fatter than american kids
story: They are piling on the pounds so fast that obesity is in danger of becoming the norm.If the trend continues, three-quarters of men and two-thirds of women will be overweight by 2030.These stark statistics were the “alarm call” which convinced Mr Hunt it was time to tackle the crisis head-on.He told The Sun on Sunday: “We have childhood obesity rates that are the third worst in Europe and our 11-year-olds have just overtaken America in terms of obesity rates.“At primary school, one in ten children arrive obese – one in five children leave obese.“It’s not a record that we can be proud of as a country and it’s why we have to change things.”He insists the only way to beat the flab is a combination of diet and exercise.But parents need support to help conquer the twin perils of cheap junk food and the internet.More than half of children spend seven hours a day on their backsides on screens instead of playing outside.Mr Hunt added: “They’re at school between nine and 3.30 and go to bed at nine or ten so they’re spending the vast chunk of their spare time sedentary.“In the 1970s and 80s, youngsters did their socialising down the street. Today they do their socialising online – and like junk food, it’s highly addictive.“We’ve got to do something about this. That’s why we want schools to play a part in getting pupils in the habit of exercising regularly.”Mr Hunt who runs up to six miles, three times a week, said he wants to help parents to help their kids.“We’re not going to halve childhood obesity through government action alone. title: britain halloumi shortage cyprus farmers demand
story: The cheese must be made from at least 20 per cent sheep and goats milk on the Mediterranean island, according to strict EU rules.But farmers are getting increasing demand from the UK - which is now the cheeses biggest market outside of Cyprus.Famed for its salty taste and meaty texture, halloumi has a high melting point making it perfect for grills or barbecues.But as Britain is on the cusp of the hottest week of the year, supermarkets are seemingly running out of stock.Twitter user Lauren, said: This is going to sound silly but... Is there a shortage of halloumi? Are people panic buying it?Ive been trying to get hold of some for 2 weeks and none of the local shops have it in stock... All I want is a salty, cheesy fix!Sue asked her followers: Is there a halloumi shortage? #asda #morrisons. Is there a national shortage????Pittas, one the main halloumi producers, says its sending emergency supplies across Europe by road to stores that dont want to wait the usual four weeks it takes to arrive by sea.Company director John Pittas told the Daily Mail: It costs more money to send it that way but Brits love their halloumi.Scientists from the university where Dolly the sheep was cloned have even waded into the apparent crisis to help farmed increase their milk production.Ricardo Pong-Wong, from the Roslin Institute at Edinburgh University, told the newspaper: The team in Cyprus are doing a fantastic job and they are already seeing benefits.It follows the excitement of Aldis halloumi fries - which flew off the shelves and left customers fuming.Scores vented on Twitter as the frozen food keeps being displayed as sold out in a string of stores across the UK.Some customers have posted pictures of empty freezers, while others have been demanding answers from the supermarket.One angry customer wrote: Sixth time the charm I thought.. title: woman yoga edge seaford head cliff
story: The bendy daredevil was spotted performing the Tree position during her 20-minute session on the chalk cliff with jagged rocks below.Despite giant cracks and signs warning walkers the cliff could give way at any moment she seemed calm as she changed poses.Tourists are often seen dangling over the deadly drop at the iconic edge of the Seaford Head cliff, in Seaford, East Sussex.A gasping crowd of bystanders gathered to watch the display.Local Wayne Spring, 51, has seen scores of people gamble with death at the site but was was shocked at the womans idiotic behaviour.He took the series of snaps to capture the breathtakingly stupid behaviour on Friday afternoon.The photographer said: I find myself questioning peoples common sense quite a lot these days, but this was just another level.It was absolutely ridiculous - at the best of times, I cant understand why anybody would go anywhere near a crumbling cliff above a sheer drop.But this was something else - I couldnt believe my eyes when she did the headstand.Wayne added: Yogas meant to be relaxing, but I can tell you that it wasnt relaxing watching her.The woman was so firm with her poses, it just goes to show that she was totally oblivious to the danger she was in.The cliffs are so unstable, they could collapse at any time.Sightseers have been warned to stay away from the edge after a series of cliff falls saw thousands of tonnes of chalk tumbling onto the beach below earlier this year.Seaford Head is along the same stretch of coastline as Beachy Head - one of the worlds most notorious cliffs.Last week seven people were found at the foot of the 530ft sheer drop.

Her next of kin have been informed and police are supporting the family.A 14 year old boy was also taken to Derriford Hospital where he remains in a critical condition.Police believe that both teenagers had suffered adverse reactions having taken an, as yet unknown, substance or substances.Police would like to speak to anyone who has information in connection with the incident including anyone who was in the area around the viaduct on Saturday afternoon.The names of the teenagers have not yet been revealed.A post mortem will be held later on the dead girl in a bid to establish what the unknown substances were.Cops are also talking to their families and friends in an effort to track down who supplied the substances.

title: theresa may being urged to urgently step up preparations for a no deal brexit to increase pressure on brussels
story: Sixty former cabinet ministers, MPs, economists and business figures signed a letter to the Prime Minister to accelerate planning to operate under World Trade Organisation rules once we leave the EU.The group argue that in order to have real leverage in the Brexit endgame the UK must reserve the right to walk away without a trade deal.They add: And take with it the £39 billion it has offered to pay as part of a divorce settlement.Signatories to the letter, organised by Economists for Free Trade, include the former chancellor Lord Lawson, ex-environment secretary Owen Paterson and one-time Wales secretary John Redwood, plus Wetherspoon boss Tim Martin and Sir Rocco Forte, chairman of Rocco Forte Hotels.In it they urge Mrs May to warn her European counterparts that despite their intransigent and punitive stance - they cannot delay or block Brexit.They go on to say: We believe you could also make clear that your preferred outcome is a free trade deal between Britain and the EU, an arrangement that is to the mutual benefit of both parties.Britain is a great champion of free trade and looks forward to striking free trade deals with countries beyond the shores of the Continent once Brexit has taken effect.However, in light of the reluctance of the EU swiftly to secure a free trade deal - eminently possible since we have been trading freely with the EU for more than 40 years - we suggest you make clear your belief that the UK has now to prepare urgently for the possibility that no agreement is forthcoming.Accordingly, we believe now is the time to issue instructions to UK authorities to accelerate their preparations for no deal and a move to a World Trade Deal under WTO rules that, after all, govern the vast majority of global trading arrangements today.The letter was released yesterday, as tens of thousands of people marched through London on the second anniversary of the EU referendum to demand a second vote on the terms of the Brexit deal.But the leading Eurosceptics insist Britain can flourish, even without a free trade deal, because of the benefits of leaving the EU.They add: This would give the Chancellor ample scope to increase spending on priority public services such as the NHS while reducing the too high UK tax burden.A Downing Street source said: We are confident of getting a good deal that delivers for every part of the UK and allows us to take back control of our money, rules and borders.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: hot dog water us festival marketing
story: Performance artist Douglas Bevans told customers the bottles, which contained a floating frankfurter, had incredible health benefits.Bevans boiled about 100 organic beef hot dogs and popped them into what appeared to be recycled Voss bottles to sell at the annual Car Free event in Vancouver.Scores of gullible punters purchased the product, believing it could increase brain function, help with weight loss and give a more youthful appearance, he claimed.The artist said he sold 60 litres worth of hot dog water at US $37.99 a bottle from his stall at the festival last Sunday.Among other marketing tricks at his booth were fake customer testimonials and lengthy descriptions of the waters properties.The promotional materials read: Because Hot Dog Water and perspiration resemble each other, when you drink Hot Dog Water it bypasses the lymphatic system whereas other waters have to go through your filtering system, so really, Hot Dog Water has three times as much uptake as coconut water.Hot Dog Water in its absurdity hopes to encourage critical thinking related to product marketing and the significant role it can play in our purchasing choices.Bevans said he came up with the stunt when he questioned the ridiculous marketing and health claims behind other products.He told The Canadian Press: I thought to myself ‘I bet I could sell hot dog water’.We noticed that some people were rubbing lip balm on their crow’s feet and they were swearing their crow’s feet were disappearing before their eyes.We’re helping people, empowering them to use informed decisions in their purchasing choices. That is the message behind this.Art, I think, has a way of doing this better than if this was a public service announcement. There’s an image attached to it, that it’s ridiculous.He said many customers were immediately impressed by by the supposed health benefits.

title: game of thrones stars kit harington and rose leslie marry at family castle
story: The actors met in 2012 while filming the long-running saga in Iceland, where they were playing Jon Snow and Ygritte. Their engagement was announced in The Times last year, and a wedding date of 23 June was posted at the Huntly registration office in Scotland.The actress - whose full name is Rose Eleanor Arbuthnot-Leslie - is a descendant of Charles II and her family owns the 12th-century Wardhill Castle in Aberdeenshire, where the ceremony took place. Her father said he was "thrilled" for his daughter as she prepared to marry her former co-star.Guests lined the path as the couple left the church after the ceremony and showered them with flower petal confetti.They got into an old land Rover Destroyer decorated with "Just Married" paper hearts and tin cans tied to the back. Speaking outside the castle before the ceremony, Sebastian Leslie said: "We are absolutely thrilled for Kit and Rose to be marrying today."Co-stars Emilia Clarke, who played Daenerys Targaryen, and Peter Dinklage, who played Tyrion Lannister, were seen arriving in nearby Aberdeen on Friday.Fans of the Sky Atlantic series had been gathering outside the castle hoping to catch a glimpse of the stars.Two Chinese students, who are currently studying in Glasgow, brought flowers.Yunyao Li, 23, and Qiong dan Xu, 23, said they were fans of Jon Snow."We would like to see him if possible," one said.The impressive castle where the wedding was held, complete with turrets and surrounded by countryside and woodland, can sleep 16 people in the main house but there are more properties in the grounds. title: liam fox prepared to accept a longer brexit transition period
story: Government sources told The Times that Mrs May is set to ask the EU for another two years of transition - extending the period before full Brexit to seven years after the public voted for it.Mr Fox told Sky News: "What I wanted was that we were outside of the single market and the customs union and outside the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice."That's where I think we're going to end up. If we do it slightly more slowly in order to minimise any disruption that's fine by me."He said an extension to the Article 50 period - which is set at two years by EU statute - would not be "politically acceptable" to him, but he refused to be drawn on whether he would resign if it did happen.But he said he would not have an issue with an extension to the transition period, which the government has said will end on 31 December, 2020, as there may be reasons why it is inevitable.Mr Fox added: "To keep Britain in the European Union would not be politically acceptable. It would not be acceptable to me."If the transition period had to be extended for technical reasons... if, for example, one other country was unable to ratify the agreement or we didn't have technical means in place and we already had the withdrawal agreement and the future economic partnership already agreed, I wouldn't have a major problem with that, as long as it was very time limited and there was a unilateral mechanism for Britain to pull out of it if we thought that we were being kept in the European Union against our will." Extending the transition period has the potential to reduce the possibility the UK would crash out of the EU without a deal - something some major companies have said would be unacceptable.Airbus, which employs 14,000 in the UK directly and is linked to 110,000 other jobs at suppliers, says a no-deal scenario would cause "chaos at the borders".

title: f business top tories launch
story: News'F*** business!' Top Tories launch 'shocking' attacks on firms over Brexit - as even Jeremy Hunt joins the frayFirst Brexiteer Boris Johnson proclaimed "f*** business!". Now Remainer Jeremy Hunt has condemned Airbus' threat to leave the UK&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter13:37, 24 JUN 2018Updated14:04, 24 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTop Tories have launched a string of shocking attacks on businesses that are warning about the effect of Brexit . The weekend began with claims Brexiteer Boris Johnson proclaimed f*** business! at a glitzy official reception. Now even Remain-backing Jeremy Hunt has joined the fray - by attacking Airbus's threat to leave the UK as completely inappropriate and demanding the firm get behind Theresa May. The aerospace giant - which has 14,000 UK staff - warned this week it will reconsider its investments in Britain if there is no Brexit deal. It was joined by Siemens and BMW, which warned it will have to start making contingency plans if there is still no clarity in the next couple of months.  Business leaders also launched an unprecedented joint attack on Theresa May's slow progress today. The CBI, Institute of Directors, British Chambers of Commerce, EEF manufacturing group and Federation of Small Businesses wrote: The clock is ticking increasingly loudly and the business community is concerned that time is running out. Yet instead of promising to speed up the pace of Brexit, Tory Cabinet ministers mounted a backlash against businesses for sounding the alarm. Health Secretary Mr Hunt urged people to ignore siren voices, telling the BBC: I thought it was completely inappropriate for businesses to be making these kinds of threats. We are at an absolutely critical moment in the Brexit discussions and what that means is that we need to get behind Theresa May to deliver the best possible Brexit - a clean Brexit.  The more that we undermine Theresa May the more likely we are to end up with a fudge, which would be an absolute disaster for everyone. Fellow Cabinet minister Liam Fox warned businesses must not force Britain to take no deal off the table - because it would hurt talks with Brussels. The Brexiteer International Trade Secretary told Sky News: I think that companies are right to say that if there’s no deal that won’t be good for Britain - but it won’t be good for Europe either. They should also be making the same case to European governments. That will be bad for them in an era where we have got complex integrated supply chains it will be necessarily bad for both sides. It comes after Boris Johnson was yesterday accused by EU diplomats of saying f*** business - at a reception to celebrate the Queen's birthday.  The Foreign Secretary is said to have uttered the reply when he was asked about business leaders' fears over leaving the EU. An ally told the Mirror Mr Johnson had no recollection of using the phrase f*** business - but did not outright deny he said it. A source close to the Cabinet minister added: He was misheard and was actually attacking lobbyists like the EU-funded CBI who are more interested in doing what's right for big multinational corporations instead of helping ordinary working Brits. Remain-backing peer Lord Rose, the former chairman of Marks and Spencer, told the Mail on Sunday Mr Johnson's alleged outburst was shocking and sad.

title: inexcusable report gosport gathered dust
story: NewsopinionInexcusable report into Gosport gathered dust for 10 years, says Shadow health secretary Jonathan AshworthThe report is clear: concerns were first raised in 1991 but Gosport War Memorial Hospital chose not to rectify the practise of prescribing the drugs involved&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJonathan Ashworth22:30, 23 JUN 2018Updated09:31, 24 JUN 2018NewsopinionAn inquiry was conduced which found an 'almost routine use of opiates' since 1998 at The Gosport War Memorial Hospital in Gosport, Hampshire (Image: PA)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWe learned this week the harrowing truth and extent of the poor care in Gosport War Memorial Hospital two decades ago. Our thoughts must be with the families of those 450 patients whose lives were shortened. What have learned this week has been quite simply devastating, shocking and heartbreaking. I pay tribute to my Liberal Democrat parliamentary colleague Norman Lamb for establishing the inquiry as minister and I thank the inquiry panel who has shown extraordinary dedication, under the calm, compassionate, relentless, determined leadership of the former Bishop of Liverpool James Jones in uncovering an injustice and revealing the truth about a shameful episode in our nation’s recent history. The Report is clear, concerns were first raised in 1991 but the hospital chose not to rectify the practise of prescribing the drugs involved. An inquiry was conduced which found an “almost routine use of opiates” since 1998, which “almost certainly shortened the lives of some patients”. But inexcusably this report was left to gather dust on a shelf for ten years. As the Rt Reverend Jones says, handing over a loved one to a hospital, to doctors and nurses, is an act of trust. That trust was betrayed. He goes on: “a large number of patients and their relatives understood that their admission to the hospital was for either rehabilitation or respite, they were, in effect, put on a terminal care pathway.” Others will come to their own judgement but for me that is unforgivable.

title: jeremy hunt ban shops selling
story: NewsJeremy Hunt to ban shops selling energy drinks to under-18s in obesity fightThe Health Secretary is appalled at new figures which show a quarter of 6 - 9 year olds knock back the caffeine laden fizzy drinks&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNigel NelsonPolitical Editor00:01, 24 JUN 2018Updated10:20, 24 JUN 2018NewsSupermarkets Asda, Waitrose, Tesco and the Co-op introduced a voluntary ban on selling energy drinks with more than 150mg of caffeine per litre earlier this year (Image: iStock Unreleased)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailChildren are to be banned from buying Red Bull and other energy drinks in an obesity crackdown by Jeremy Hunt. The Health Secretary is appalled at new figures which show a quarter of youngsters aged six to nine knock back the fizzy products, which are laden with sugar and caffeine. So today he will announce a consultation on plans to stop shops selling them to under-18s in a bid to halve childhood obesity by 2030. Mr Hunt will say: “It is near impossible to shield children from exposure to unhealthy foods. Parents are asking for help.  “It’s our job to give them power to make healthier choices and make their lives easier in doing so.” Supermarkets Asda, Waitrose, Tesco and the Co-op introduced a voluntary ban on selling energy drinks with over 150mg of caffeine a litre earlier this year. Red Bull and similar drinks can contain as much caffeine as a strong coffee and up to a dozen teaspoonfuls of sugar. Shops will also be stopped from putting sweets at checkouts or offering them in buy-one-get-one-free deals.  TV ads promoting foods high in fat, sugar or salt are likely to be banned before the 9pm watershed and there will be mandatory calorie labelling in restaurants, cafes and takeaways. Public Health England boss Duncan Selbie welcomed what he called “bold steps” in the war on rising childhood obesity. Cancer Research UK and Diabetes UK also backed Mr Hunt’s plans. But Shadow Health Secretary Jonathan Ashworth said: “We need bold action not another watered-down, lame duck strategy.”  “It’s our job to give them power to make healthier choices and to make their life easier in doing so. “The cost of obesity – both on individual lives and to our NHS – is too great to ignore.” Supermarkets Asda, Waitrose, Tesco and the Co-op introduced a voluntary ban on selling energy drinks with more than 150mg of caffeine per litre earlier this year. Mr Hunt will go further and make it illegal for all shops to sell the drinks to kids, and is considering putting them on a par with alcohol so only over 18s can buy them. Stores will also be stopped from putting tempting sweets at check-outs where children pester their parents for them, or including them in buy-one-get-one-free offers. TV ads promoting high fat, sugar or salt foods are likely to be banned before the 9pm watershed and there will be mandatory calorie labelling in restaurants, cafes and takeaways.

title: suspended labour mp john woodcock
story: NewsSuspended Labour MP John Woodcock refuses to co-operate with 'tainted' sexual harassment probeJeremy Corbyn critic John Woodcock demanded a "genuinely independent" investigation and told Labour: "You have shown disregard for the law"&nbspShareByDan BloomPolitical reporter11:09, 24 JUN 2018NewsJeremy Corbyn critic John Woodcock has demanded a genuinely independent investigation (Image: REX/Shutterstock)&nbspShareGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA suspended MP is refusing to co-operate with Labour's sexual harassment probe into him - claiming it is tainted and biased.  Jeremy Corbyn critic John Woodcock has demanded a genuinely independent investigation and told Labour's general secretary: You have shown disregard for the law.  The Barrow and Furness MP was suspended from Labour in April over leaked claims he sent inappropriate texts and emails to a former staffer.  Mr Woodcock vehemently denies the claims, which are still under investigation by the Labour Party .  In a personal letter to Labour general secretary Jennie Formby, the MP said: I am writing to notify you that I am withdrawing my co-operation from your tainted disciplinary process.  He requested that she make arrangements to transfer the complaint into the hands of a Parliamentary probe or appropriately qualified, independent arbiter. Regardless of whether other Labour members share my misgivings about Jeremy Corbyn and John McDonnell, no one should be prepared to tolerate the disdain for due process and the rule of law that has been allowed to fester within Labour, he wrote. He added: You have shown disregard for the law by completely ignoring my formal request to release by the legally stipulated date information held about me by the party. That information was requested at the beginning of May and should have been provided promptly - in any event no later than the statutory deadline of 13 June. I've not even had the courtesy of an acknowledgement.  This has left me in the position of having to threaten to take you to court to make you comply with the basic legal responsibility you have to every member of the party. Mr Woodcock's lawyers, Hamlins LLP, have also sent a letter to Labour officials demanding they restore integrity to the probe after it was affected by a poisonous atmosphere towards non-Corbyn-backing MPs. The letter claims details of the case were leaked to the media in a co-ordinated campaign to undermine and discredit our client. This obviously raises serious doubt about the integrity of the complaints process with which he was co-operating fully, it adds. The letter goes on to say Ms Formby wants to ditch Blairities while Mr Woodcock has been personally attacked by the general secretary of Unite. In the circumstances, it is hard to avoid the conclusion that person or persons close to this process have set out to cause our client harm, the letter adds.

title: tory jeremy hunt humiliated live
story: NewsTory Jeremy Hunt humiliated on live TV as he disagrees with HIMSELF over BrexitThe Health Secretary was ambushed spectacularly by BBC host Andrew Marr after he claimed "a lot of experts have been proved wrong" about Brexit&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter11:50, 24 JUN 2018Updated13:40, 24 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTory Jeremy Hunt has been left humiliated after he accidentally disagreed with HIMSELF on live TV. The Health Secretary was ambushed spectacularly by BBC host Andrew Marr after he claimed a lot of experts have been proved wrong about Brexit. Mr Hunt was trying to back Theresa May's claim that there will be a 'Brexit dividend' to fund the NHS after Britain leaves the EU. So he was confronted with a quote by one such expert who said it wouldn't exist. Bullish Mr Hunt was asked if he agreed with the expert, and replied: No. He was then immediately told the expert was, in fact, himself.  Mr Hunt made the original comment in the House of Commons on 6 July 2016 - two weeks after the country voted to leave the EU. At the time he told MPs not to trust claims by Vote Leave, led by Boris Johnson, that Britain could reclaim &pound350million a week of EU budget payments to spend on the NHS. Mr Hunt said in 2016: Even the net figure - the more like &pound100 million net contribution that we make to the EU - is not a figure that we can bank on with any certainty.  Because , even if it did materialise after an exit from the EU, it would be negated by the very smallest of contractions in the economy. [That] would itself reduce the tax base and the amount of public spending available.  Confronted with his quote today, Mr Hunt said he didn't agree with it. Told it was in fact by him, the flustered Cabinet minister took a couple of seconds to register, then said: I don't agree with the line of questioning. Mr Marr replied: That's your own quote!  It comes after PM Theresa May unveiled the health service's 70th birthday present - &pound20.5billion a year in extra real terms funding by 2024. But claims the 3.4% rise would be funded by a Brexit dividend unravelled after economists and Tory MPs said it did not exist. Mrs May admitted much of the cash will come from higher taxes, yet has not said what those taxes will be. During a testy exchange Mr Hunt refused to guarantee the Tories would keep their pledge to cut corporation tax to 17%. Instead he said all will be revealed within six months at the Budget.

title: 11 best spots uk watch
story: Advertorial11 best spots in the UK to watch an amazing sunset this summerThis week marks the summer solstice – and is also the official start of summer. So what better time to explore the UK and take in some of the country’s most breathtaking bike rides?&nbspShareByHolly Thatcher14:24, 22 JUN 2018Updated21:07, 23 JUN 2018Advertorial (Image: Getty)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWe've been blessed with some decent weather already in 2018 - but this week is when summer *officially* begins. June 21, the summer solstice in the Northern Hemisphere, is the longest day in the year - affording us approximately 17 hours of daylight. Technically, this also means that the nights will start drawing in again now - so there's really no time like the present to get out and explore the great outdoors on some of the country’s most breathtaking bike rides. We've taken a look around the UK to find the best places to watch the sun setting. 1. Museum of Scottish Lighthouses, Fraserburgh, Scotland  A small village called Maud in Aberdeenshire offers a starting place for a traffic-free cycle to the coast. If you're in the mood to learn then head to the Museum of Scottish Lighthouses in Fraserburgh. The sun will set at around 10.12pm this week in this part of Scotland, so you've got loads of time to enjoy the start of the summer. Bike need replacing?   If your existing bike needs replacing, you'll want something efficient and speedy for the roads - like the Carrera Parva Hybrid bike , which comes in versions for both men and women and is now just &pound210 (a saving of &pound90). And if you don't need a new bike, why not have yours checked over before setting off. Like any mode of transport your bike needs to be looked after and regularly checked for wear and tear. Halfords offers a 32-point Free Bike Check which includes:  Frame, saddle and handlebar Wheels including tyres, rims, spokes and hubs Brake system including levers, calipers, pads and cables / hoses Drivetrain including gears, levers, chain, bottom bracket, cranks and cables  2. The Eden Project, Cornwall   Why not spend the day enjoying the amazing sights at the Eden Project? Best of all, if you arrive by bike you'll get a discount on entry. The sun sets on Eden at around 9:30pm on the solstice. Bear in mind though that the Eden Project shuts at 6pm, so you'll need to watch the sun go down somewhere nearby.  Get there in style on the Carrera Subway 1 Hybrid Bike , &pound300. With easy to use 24 speed Shimano gearing, your effort for building speed will be minimised on all terrains, while its lightweight aluminium frame means you can quickly and efficiently ride to your destination. Camping out?   Planning to camp? Be sure you book in advance as you won't want to be without a pitch. Croft Farm Holiday Park is just a mile from the Eden Project and three miles from the beach. Pentewan Sands is also nearby and boasts amazing family facilities - as well as the nearby Pentewan Cycle Trail. Consider taking a Halfords Vis A Vis 4 Person Tent with you, which is currently reduced to just &pound60, (was &pound150, save &pound90). The simple tunnel design is easy to pitch in approximately 20 minutes. With two separate bedrooms and a living area, it's perfect for families or groups of friends. For additional comfort pack an Urban Escape Folding Table And Bench Set , &pound40 (was &pound50, save &pound10) which folds down into a single carry case to make it easy to transport and store.  3. Pembrokeshire Coast National Park, Wales  The Pembrokeshire Coast Path is an absolutely beautiful part of Wales and a stunning place to watch the sun go down. There are loads of campsites in the area, including some unique places to stay. There are plenty of bike routes too, with some offering traffic-free options if you want a more peaceful ride. In Pembrokeshire you can expect the sun to set around 9:39pm. Why not try..   The Boardman ADV 8.8 Adventure Bike , &pound750, is a bike truly made to help you explore new possibilities. This bike is adept at riding in comfort on roads but really excels when you want to get off the beaten track.   4. White Nancy, Cheshire   Located on Kerridge Hill, White Nancy is a local landmark from which you can see all around the area, from Wales to the west and the Pennines to the north. From time to time White Nancy is painted to look like other things, like a Christmas pudding or with Olympic rings when London hosted in 2012. The sun will set over White Nancy at around 9:36 this week. Need to drive?  Heading further afield to enjoy the sunny days? If you're packing up the whole family into the car for a camping trip, make sure it's in good running order first. A Free Car Check performed by Halfords experts will put your mind at rest. Book online or just pop in to your local Halfords store and trained colleagues will carry out a free car bulb check and check your battery, wiper blades, engine oil level and air conditioning, and check for any windscreen chips. They'll even give you a free screenwash top-up too.  If you're making an unfamiliar journey, don't forget to get the Garmin Drive Sat Nav , &pound79.99 (was &pound99.99, save &pound20.99). With lifetime map updates you're never going to find yourself driving down a newly-closed street or down a disused road. 5. Edinburgh Castle, Scotland  There are few places that are as stunning as Edinburgh Castle, located atop Castle Rock. The views of Edinburgh from the castle are amazing, and a great place to watch the end of the day roll around. Sunset here will take place at 9:58pm. 6. Hampstead Heath, London  The scenery on Hampstead Heath always pleases the eye. This amazing part of London has views of every landmark you could hope for and it's a wonderful place to watch the sun go down. This will happen at around 9:18pm in the capital.   7. Osborne House, Isle of Wight   The home of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert is quite a sight to see. Accessible by bike (and ferry, if you're not an island resident), it's the ideal place to see during the day before you settle down somewhere to watch the sunset. If you're up for the cycle, Shanklin Chine on the west of the island is well worth an evening visit.  Do it with ease - and classic style - on the Pendleton Somerby Electric Hybrid Bike , &pound750. With added electrically powered pedal assistance, it delivers 40 - 50 miles of range through a rear hub motor with speed sensor. This extra power is enough to guarantee effortless rides, taking the strain out of hills and making moving off from a standstill much easier. If you prefer, this bike is also available in a non electric version and in a range of colours - we love the mint green ! The sunset starts at 9:18pm near Osborne House and 9:17pm in Shanklin Chine.  8. Ness Point, Lowestoft    Ness Point is the UK's most easterly point. This makes it a great place to ride to on National Cycle Route 1. Make yourself comfortable on the Halfords XL Waterproof Picnic Blanket , &pound10 (half price) and watch the waves crash in as the sun goes down. Sunset is 9:16 at the UK's most easterly point.  9. Blackpool Pleasure Beach, Lancashire   With plenty of places to cycle in the area you could have an amazing day out in Blackpool. Start with a ride to the Pleasure Beach, and have some fun with the kids (or without them!) on the roller coasters. When all that's done you can have fish and chips while the sun sets on another day. The sun will go set at around 9:43 in Blackpool.  10. Cotswolds, England  Spread over six counties there's a lot to see in the Cotswolds. Consider taking a ride through the picturesque Castle Combe to take in the amazing houses and the stunning market square. The sun sets on this beautiful village at 9:26pm  Find your way by car - and beat the traffic   If you're driving to somewhere new then why not add a sat nav to your car? The TomTom GO 6200 , &pound270, (was &pound339.99, save &pound69.99) adds real-time traffic information to the navigational benefits of a sat nav (smartphone required for this feature).   11. Giant's Causeway, Northern Ireland

story: NewsBrave mum battered by her boyfriend shares horrific pictures of her injuries caused by ex-boyfriend's brutal abuseJade wants readers to see the horrific images in the hope it would encourage other people suffering domestic violence to come forward about their abuse&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByLuke TraynorPippa Allen-Kinross13:42, 24 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA courageous mum-of-three has shared horrific photographs of the injuries caused by the brutal abuse of her thug ex-boyfriend.  Jade Brett-Moore shared the appalling photographs to encourage other victims of domestic violence come forward about the abuse they are suffering, after her ex Daniel McLean was jailed for four years for the countless attacks against her.  The pictures shared by the 23-year-old show how her whole body was subjected to vicious attacks, with McLean even using a deliberately-sharpened end of a metal broom stick to cut at her legs. I'd say to those out there that right now, whatever place and whatever you're in, you might see it as being impossible to break free, and while you're in it you just think there's no way of ever getting out of it and you're stuck in that. Jade, writing after he was sent down last week, said: So this[McLean] is my babies' father, sadly, who most of you will already know because of his pathetic reputation. Who not only put me through five years, on and off, of hell, but who knew I'd gone through hell with a previous partner who was convicted and justice was served. Really, I should have listened to my family back then and real friends who warned me. But he was adamant he had changed, so I gave it a last shot. I was his victim of abuse and torture. I couldn't eat, I was losing weight rapidly and he knew I had an eating disorder... Jade added: He wouldn't let me shower on my own or go the toilet on my own, in case I was sneaking someone else in. I wasn't allowed out anywhere I couldn't wear make-up or nice clothes because I was a 'slag'. He called me anorexic, then said I was fat, always brought me down on how I looked, and that I was unattractive which made me feel so insecure, told me no-one would ever want me because of my life... story: NewsBritain is on the brink of a halloumi shortage - and cheese lovers are heartbrokenReports say farmers are struggling to meet demand for the Cypriot cheese&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByCourtney Pochin12:40, 24 JUN 2018Updated13:07, 24 JUN 2018NewsCheese lovers are heartbroken by the thought of a halloumi shortage (Image: Dorling Kindersley)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWe're officially cheesed off! That's because it's been reported that Britain is facing a halloumi shortage, as farmers in Cyprus are finding it difficult to meet demand for the cheese. The semi-hard cheese, made from a mixture of goat's milk and sheep's milk has become incredibly popular of late, with foodies enjoying everything from halloumi fries to halloumi burgers. As the perfect addition to any grill, the cheese is expected to be a must-have at summer BBQs this year - but shoppers might find it difficult to pick up a pack of the tasty treat.  According to social media users, supermarkets appear to be running out of stock. Twitter user Lauren said: This is going to sound silly but... Is there a shortage of halloumi? Are people panic buying it? I've been trying to get hold of some for two weeks and none of the local shops have it in stock... All I want is a salty, cheesy fix! Another wrote: Been to two different shops now and NEITHER had any halloumi is this a joke?? Is there a national shortage???  One person even said they were heartbroken by the thought of Britain running out of the rubbery cheese.  Pittas, one of the main producers of halloumi, told the Mail Online that it is sending emergency supplies across Europe by road to stores that don't want to wait the usual four weeks it takes to arrive by sea.  Company director John Pittas said: It costs more money to send it that way but Brits love their halloumi. Scientists from the Roslin Institute at Edinburgh University, where Dolly the sheep was cloned, have now gotten involved in the crisis, helping farmers increase their milk production.

title: britains most pothole plagued roads
story: NewsBritain's most pothole-plagued roads revealed as councils heave with complaintsShocking survey across country comes after study found our roads are worse than in Chile, Oman and Peru, with one expert branding it a 'national disgrace'&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNicola Small21:32, 23 JUN 2018Updated13:48, 24 JUN 2018NewsBetween 2007 and 2016, 22 cyclists were killed and 368 were seriously injured due to crumbling roads, with the victim toll rising, figures show (Image: E+)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe nation’s most pothole-plagued roads are today revealed after a Sunday Mirror investigation. We surveyed every local authority to compile the list of shame – the streets that drew the most complaints. Our research was carried out after a study showed roads in Britain are worse than in Chile, Oman and Peru. And they are deadly. Between 2007 and 2016, 22 cyclists were killed and 368 were &shyseriously injured due to crumbling roads, with the victim toll rising. Last year an inquest heard Roger Hamer, 83, died from severe brain &shyinjuries after being flung off his bike when it hit a pothole in Ramsbottom, Greater Manchester.  We found the country’s worst road is Mellor Brook Bypass near Balderstone, Lancs. Motorists and cyclists reported it to the council 545 times in one year. Freedom of Information requests show Seven Hills Road in Elmbridge, Surrey, caused the second highest number of complaints, with 216 reported. Hundreds of drivers signed a petition demanding that the county council resurfaced it. One resident said they had seen FIVE different cars changing tyres at the &shyroadside, adding: “I will be avoiding this road until it is repaired.”  Another motorist said: “Incredibly dangerous trying to avoid huge, deep potholes, having to veer into oncoming traffic. Fed up with damage to my car. “Are they waiting for another needless death? Stop treating us with contempt.” Shocked drivers are hitting potholes and ruining tyres and their cars’ &shysuspensions, steering and underbodies, or losing control and having crashes. Edmund King, the president of the AA, said our investigation shows that right across the country, “our potholed roads are a national disgrace”, and are “fast becoming a national emergency”.  He said: “We are rescuing record numbers of drivers whose vehicles are damaged by potholes. Insurance claims for damage caused by potholes is soaring. “The lack of &shyinvestment on local roads means highway authorities are doing little more than papering over cracks, with drivers picking up the pieces.” He said February’s Beast from the East had made it worse – but was simply exposing years of &shyunderinvestment by cash-strapped councils. In the first four months of 2018, AA Insurance received more pothole claims than in the whole of 2017.  Our probe comes after the Asphalt Industry Alliance revealed 24,500 miles of local roads will need to be shut for repairs in the next year – and it would take at least 14years to clear the backlog, costing &pound9.3billion. A separate report by Cycling UK found local authorities have forked out &pound43.4million in compensation and legal costs due to potholes over the past five years. Sam Jones, of Cycling UK, said: “Before spending &pound15billion on new motorways and trunk roads, let’s fix the roads we use every day and are essential for us to get to work and drop the kids off at school.” National roads are to get 52 times more government funding by 2020 compared to local roads. Councillor Martin Tett, of the LocalGovernment &shyAssociation, said: “Only long-term, consistent and fairer investment in local roads can let councils embark on the improvements so desperately needed.”

title: harry kane swore would win
story: NewsHarry Kane swore he would win World Cup when he was just SEVEN as he prepares for Panama clashThe hero skipper told school pals about his devotion to the Three Lions ahead of tomorrow’s match in Nizhny Novgorod&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByPatrick Hill22:30, 23 JUN 2018NewsHarry Kane has dreamed of winning the trophy since his schooldays (Image: Daily Mirror)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email When Harry Kane leads the Three Lions out tomorrow, he moves a step closer to the goal he set aged seven.   Former school pal and footie team-mate Luke Robinson has &shyrevealed the England skipper – at the time sporting a David Beckham mohican – told him he was going to win the World Cup one day.  Speaking of Harry’s dream ahead of tomorrow’s Panama clash, Luke said: “He loved England and even then one of his biggest dreams was to play for England and win the World Cup. We’d watch the World Cup together and he was always a very proud England fan. “During the 2002 World Cup, Harry had his England shirt with Beckham on the back and the Beckham mohican. “He was so passionate, he was devastated when we went out.”  Luke, 24, was with Harry when he lifted the Essex &amp Waltham Forest District Cup as a 12-year-old in 2006. Now he, like the rest of the &shynation, hopes Harry will lift the coveted FIFA World Cup Trophy on July 15. And teacher Luke said if Harry does win the &shyultimate prize, it will be his proudest &shymoment. He said: “I remember once when Brazil were playing and they had the likes of Ronaldinho, Ronaldo and Roberto Carlos – some of my &shyfavourite players. “I was saying, ‘I’d love to play for Brazil!’. But Harry was like, ‘No, it’s got to be England! I’d love to play for England. That’s the country! That’s the thing!’. He’s that type of guy, England and proud.”  On Harry’s dedication, he said: “Everything was football. If he wasn’t watching football, he was speaking about football, playing football in the park or playing it on the computer. He did well at school and was good at other sports, like cricket, but it was football all day, every day. “In catering class, we had to bring a recipe and make a meal. He’d get a recipe from his chef at Tottenham and cook that so it was healthy. “He’s massive now but at school he was five foot eight or nine, and podgy. He shot up at 16 or 17. He did running and trained three or four times a week. By 16 or 17 he was fit as a fiddle. He put in years of dedication.”  Harry got England off to a flying start last Monday, scoring both goals in a dramatic 2-1 win against Tunisia – and Luke said the display was classic Kane. He said: “Back in school we knew if we needed a goal Harry could always get it. He’s still that sort of player now and the way he popped up with the winner against Tunisia was like back in his schooldays. I don’t see why he can’t win the golden boot.” Harry, 24, leads the line again today against minnows Panama. England’s second Group G game kicks off in Nizhny Novgorod, western Russia, at 1pm our time.  And someone else tipping him to go all the way is Ian Marshall, the chairman of Harry’s first team, Ridgeway Rovers – where Beckham also started out. And he said: “I bet if Harry won the World Cup he’d come back and see us with it. He’s a class act and we’re so proud. For a club like us to have two England captains in Harry and David, it’s something to shout about.” Meanwhile, England is set for a &pound382million party as it cheers on Harry and his boys today.  Retail experts reckon &pound65million will be spent in pubs, cafes and restaurants and &pound151million will go on food and drink at home. Some &pound20million will go on flags and souvenirs, &pound68million on shirts and &pound67million on TVs, website VoucherCodes and the Centre for Retail Research said.  Tesco expects to sell 140 million bottles and cans of beer. The chain’s booze boss Rob Cooke said: “There’s a real party atmosphere.”  Big brother's watching you Harry Kane has his biggest fan cheering him on in Russia – his lookalike older brother Charlie.
